article-meta.product: PaolicelliRC BolascoG PaganiF MaggiL ScianniM PanzanelliP GiustettoM FerreiraTA GuiducciE DumasL and others. 2011. Synaptic pruning by microglia is necessary for normal brain development. Science. 333:1456–1458.

body.p: Microglia, abundant non-neuronal cells derived from myeloid progenitors, provide a critically important surveillance and scavenging function, engulfing and clearing damaged cellular debris following brain insults. Emerging evidence also suggests that microglia may play an important role in monitoring and maintaining synapses within the healthy, uninjured brain, where motile microglial processes make frequent, transient contacts with synapses. It has, in fact, been suggested that microglia may be involved in synapse maturation or elimination. Now Paolicelli and others (2011) report that synaptic pruning by microglia is necessary for normal brain development. They report the presence of immunosignal for PSD95, a marker of excitatory postsynaptic densities, within microglial processes in the mouse hippocampus. They also demonstrate a deficit in synaptic pruning within hippocampal pyramidal neurons in mice lacking the fractalkine receptor (Cx3cr1), which is expressed by microglia and is essential to their migration. The authors interpret these results as suggesting that microglia play a major role in synaptic pruning during postnatal development in mice, and they suggest that deficits in microglial function may contribute to synaptic abnormalities in neurodevelopmental disorders.

title-group.article-title: Mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake and synaptic plasticity

article-meta.product: KimHY LeeKY LyY WangJ CuiL KimSJ ChungJM ChungK . 2011. Mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake is essential for synaptic plasticity in pain. J Neurosci. 31(36):12982–12991.

body.p: Although it is well-established that long-term potentiation (LTP) involves Ca2+ influx, largely via activated NMDA receptors, downstream effects of increased cytosolic Ca2+ are complex and only partly understood. A number of lines of evidence have suggested that mitochondria may modulate synaptic plasticity via their ability to sequester calcium. Kim and others (2011) now report a study in which they have explored the role of mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake in synaptic plasticity in the spinal cord in the capsaicin model of pain. They report that increased cytosolic Ca2+ does not trigger synaptic plasticity in a direct manner but, on the contrary, must first enter into mitochondria. Blockade of mitochondrial Ca2+ sequestration during the period of Ca2+ increase blocks the induction of pain, as well as the accompanying downstream cascade, resulting in attenuation of spinal LTP. The authors also report that experimental reduction of the accompanying mitochondrial superoxide levels reduces hyperalgesia and induction of spinal LTP. They interpret these results as indicating that mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake, and resultant production of reactive oxygen species, are required for synaptic plasticity that contributes to chronic pain. If this contention is correct, pharmacological manipulation of mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake might provide a novel approach to pharmacotherapy for pain.
